title: How COVID-19 pandemic changed work pattern? - Quora

response.answer_text: I work as a nurse and a lot has changed since the COVID-19 pandemic. I can't even enter the hospital without filling out a mandatory questionnaire regarding COVID-19 symptoms. After providing negative answers to all of the questions I am provided a surgical mask to wear for the entirety of my shift. All of my patients are swabbed for COVID-19 before they are admitted to the labor and delivery unit. COVID-19-positive patients are kept on the antepartum unit at the end of the hallway. Every so often I am pulled to antepartum to take care of COVID-19-positive mothers and their infants. I have to wear full PPE and do my charting in an empty room far away from the nurses' station. I get my blood drawn every two weeks to test for COVID-19 antibodies. It has been a big adjustment, but I actually don't mind taking care of COVID-19 patients. Sometimes I go in place of co-workers who would rather not do it. Once I meet the patient with COVID-19 my anxiety totally subsides. I'm reminded that I'm caring for an actual person rather than a scary diagnosis.

For me, I have had to train most of my clients online using Zoom, Whatsapp, Skype, or Webex, or any varient of a video-chat app. Also, as a personal trainer, I am limited to the amount of exercise accessories I can use on my clients because, well, most of us don’t have a well-stocked gym in our homes. Some clients do have dumbbells, barbells, weight balls, a squat rack, etc. But many of my clients just have a few little dumbbells or they may not have anything at all except the furniture in their home. In addition, because I am training clients in their homes, I have to take in consideration the space where they work. fortunately, staying fit with limited resources isn’t hard. For one, I have them get creative and use water bottles for weights, towels for sliders (if they have hardwood floor) or rice bags for lifting. In addition, much of my training has shift to functional/bodymovement exercise, and one can do a lot with just their body alone when it comes to different exercises. I have also become more adapted to teaching fitness classes on line, which means I had to rearrange some things in my bedroom so that I could be fully viewed by those taking the classes. Of course, there’s still some things I have to work out, such as video lighting and what not, but so far it’s been good When I do train people in-person, I wear a mask while training them, and for the part, I no longer touch them (when you are doing personal training, you may touch the person to make sure they’re in proper form, etc). Also, so far, I’ve been training my in-person clients either outside or in the garage, but not in their homes. And since gyms are no longer open (or at least, not in my area yet) I have had to build up my own gym, and I have learned more about body movement, and this is what I have been teaching my clients. I have never been at home so much in my life, but it has had advantages and disadvantages. In some ways I have had some better success with online training than when I was doing training at the gym, even. Anyway, that’s how things have changed for work, at least for me.

I can do most of my work from home, so I have been spending more time at home instead of at my desk. I still have to go into work if I need to use the high-end mapping program. Google Maps is fine for preliminary drafts, but sometimes you need something a little more professional. Our IT department is working to get me access to almost everything online, but it requires using a company laptop which are in short supply. I can wait. I have been using my personal equipment so far and I don't mind going in to work a couple of times each week.

I can’t work at all. I’m retired but had been stretching my savings by delivering groceries for Instacart. I made some money, enjoyed working with the people in the supermarket, and liked interacting with my customers, too. However, I’m 78, have a compromised immune system from arthritis treatments, and have COPD. If I get the bug, the chances are pretty close to 100% that it will kill me. Right now, Instacart shoppers — I know a few who are still doing it — are making very good money. Tips are way up, I guess because people appreciate not having to shop for themselves. It kills me to hear how much I could make if I were still working. But you can’t spend it if you’re dead, and I do have some fallback savings. Life is all about reacting to the curve balls.

Every morning when I enter my office building I have to have my temperature taken. Everyone else in the building does also. Then in the office where I work my coworkers & I social distance. Half the workers now work in another room. We are required to wear masks everywhere except when we’re sitting at our own desks & while we’re eating lunch.

Because people have no immunity to this deadly virus, and because systems were not in place to handle a pandemic, the only recourse is to prevent people infecting others. This virus attacks the lungs, heart, brain, kidneys and other organs. Keeping people apart is like having a vaccine until one arrives. Doug

Yes! Both in a good and bad way. Personally, on a positive side,I have been more focused on my career and hobbies now.Very,Very close to being a workaholic XD The flip side being some days are filled with procrastination,lazy and physical workout gets compromised too. Additionally,the feeling of “work environment” ,is gone. Because home is not meant to be a work environment unless you have separate designated space for it. Otherwise,your attention gets divided. Being addicted to social media or in general phone usage and other streaming platforms have increased which might make us very lazy and forget healthy habits.
